results.title: The Burning question
results.creator_credit: David Guy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
When David moved from the city, he fulfilled a lifetime dream to live in a place he had always visited and dreamed of owning. Losing almost all of his property, he is faced with a burning question in this first-hand account of the devastating Gippsland bushfires.
This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Arts Victoria and Latrobe City.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Guy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Floods through fire
results.creator_credit: Lynda Code, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Lynda Code recalls the hardships of living through the Gippsland bushfires then having to cope with devastating floods. Her story of resiliance is a tribute to her family, who have battled along with her. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Arts Victoria and Latrobe City.

results.title: Me do
results.brief_description:
Gabrielle recounts her struggle to gain independence, aided by the love and support of her mother and eight siblings.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: City of chromatic dissolution
results.brief_description:
Arthur and Corinne Cantrill used footage of Melbourne’s cityscapes and buildings from the mid 1980s to create this evocative piece on movement, colour and the city. The various parts of inner city Melbourne were originally shot on black and white negative in three colour separation, then printed on Eastmancolor film. The results are static shots of the city, where the movement of people and vehicles have a quality that is colour saturated and ghostly. This is complemented with a sountrack both urban and discordant in tone.
This is one of a series of films made by the Cantrills that experiment with dramatic distortions of colour through three-colour separation processes. The original inspiration for this project (as the filmmakers report in the final edition of Cantrills Filmnotes) came back in the mid-1970s when Kodak stopped making the Cantrills’ preferred 16mm reversal colour film stocks.

results.title: Yehinat fekir
results.brief_description: ‘Yehinat fekir’ means a mother’s love. I was born in Sudan and this is my story about my mother and how she struggled to bring us to Australia.

results.title: Graham Baxter: park ranger
results.creator_credit: Rob Salvatore and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: Only a fortunate few live and work in a place as beautiful as this. Wilson’s Promontory Park Ranger Graham Baxter explains why every day for him is a special day in this place ‘for the soul’.

results.title: Warriors and dancers
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Narjiic Day-Burns
results.brief_description:
Narjiic’s passion for music and dance began in Year 10 when he was asked to perform for NAIDOC Week. From there he joined various dance groups performing all over Victoria including his home town Echuca, finally enrolling at Swinburne. Today he blends a fusion of traditional dance with hip-hop as a way of expressing his thoughts and emotions. Dance has become a part of his life.
Music by Fonetik.
